Award.AwardTitle: CompCog: Developing a Theory of Causal Learning over Time

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Learning from experience is a critical tool for how humans successfully predict and adjust to their changing world, whether a teacher trying to figure out which pedagogical technique will work best for a class, a doctor trying to figure out which medicine will work best for patient, or a business person trying to figure out which marketing strategy will produce the largest sales. The goal of this project is to better understand how people learn cause-effect relations and make causal judgments in a highly complex world. This will facilitate predicting when humans are likely to make good decisions and when humans are likely to make bad decisions, which can be costly for the individual and for society.

The research on how people learn causal relations has primarily focused on learning in independent and identically distributed, cross-sectional situations. However, humans also learn causal relations among events that are distributed in time, which often involves non-stationary and autocorrelated information. The first goal of this work is to identify processes people use to learn causal relationships in these longitudinal situations. The second goal is to identify people's ability to employ different learning strategies adaptively for both longitudinal and cross-sectional environments. The results will also be used to develop online simulations to help students learn how to make good causal judgments when designing and analyzing research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research conducted under this grant helps to uncover how people learn cause-effect relations, for example how a patient starting to take a new medication comes to believe that the medication is working or not, or how a parent starting to use a new technique to reward their child for good behavior comes to believe whether the technique is working or not. One of the challenges of learning cause-effect relations is that the outcomes can change over time. For example, when starting to take a new medication for allergies, it can be difficult to know if the allergy medication worked, or if the allergies just got better because the weather has changed. The current research focused on if, when, and how people are able to accurately infer causal relations despite the outcomes changing over time. We have a number of key insights:

  • When faced with situation like the examples above, people often focus on the change in the cause (e.g., stopping and starting the medicine) and the change in the effect (e.g., whether the allergy symptoms have gotten better or worse). They often do this instead of or in addition to focusing on the states of the cause (e.g., whether then medicine was taken or not) and effect (e.g., whether the symptoms are bad or not). Focusing on change is actually useful from a statistical perspective becaues it helps to account for gradual trends (e.g., the allergies have gradually been getting worse over time.) Overall, this allows people to come to roughly correct causal judgments most of the time.
  • We have also found that people use a 'simplifying' heuristic of focusing just on whether the effect increased or decreased (e.g., did the allergies get better or worse) rather than focusing on the amount of increase or decrease (e.g., the allergies got a lot better vs. a little bit better). This seems to be a way that people simplify the learning process.

We have also conducted a number of studies on how people learn about multiple different causes of an outcome (e.g., learning all the factors that affect one's sleep, such as taking melatonin, exercise, coffee, drinking alcohol, weather, etc.). When there are multiple potential causes it can be quite challenging to figure out which ones actually influence one's sleep. We have two key findings:

  • We have found that people use a similar strategy to the above cases - they primarily focus on changes in each of the causes and changes in the effect (e.g., did one's sleep improve when their stress decreased) rather than focusing on the presence vs. absence of the cause and effect (e.g., did one sleep better on days with low vs. high stress).
  • We also found that people are more skeptical of inferring causal relations when two variables change at once. For example, if a person's sleep improves after becoming less stressed and also stopping drinking coffee, the person would likely have difficulty knowing if the stress, or the coffee, or both made a difference in their sleep.

We have also conducted a series of studies on how people plan ahead when testing the influence of a cause on an effect. For example, when starting to test a new antihistamine, should one take it for a week, and then stop taking it for a week, to see if it works? Deciding how to plan is complicated for two reasons. On the one hand, some medicines (or causes more generally) take repeated use for them to work, requiring that one tries them repeatedly (e.g., try it for a whole week). On the other hand, when the outcome (e.g., allergies) can fluctuate over time due to other causes (e.g., weather), it is important to compare the medication vs. no medication, back and forth, otherwise it could seem like the medication is effective just because the weather happened to change at the same time as starting the medication. There were two main conclusions from these studies:

  • People clearly understand that certain causes need to be tried repeatedly before they become effective, and adjust their testing strategies appropriately.
  • However, people have more difficulty understanding the necessity of alternating between medication vs. no medication to avoid reaching inappropriate conclusions.

In sum, our research has revealed a number of ways in which peoples' causal learning abilities are quite strong, suggesting that people often come to fairly good conclusions about the cause-effect relations. On the other hand, we have identified a couple of ways that people simplify the process of learning cause-effect relations, which can lead to suboptimal conclusions. This research suggests that people could benefit from taking courses or participating in training to learn how to figure out cause-effect relations in their lives.
